newsitem.title: GERMANY: SOCCER-TALE OF TWO SEASONS NOT LOST ON LAMBERT.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-TALE OF TWO SEASONS NOT LOST ON LAMBERT.

text.p: This time last year, Paul Lambert was relaxing after another season with Motherwell in his native Scotland.
"We'd just finished the season and we'd just managed to stay in the premier division. It was a big relief," he told Reuters.
Now, Lambert is a Borussia Dortmund regular looking forward to a mouth-watering European Cup final against Juventus in Munich's Olympic Stadium.

The contrast between struggling against the drop in one of Europe's less glamorous leagues and playing for the biggest prize in continental club soccer just a year later is not lost on the midfielder.
"It's unbelievable," said the 27-year-old, who arrived in Dortmund as a virtual unknown on a free transfer last summer.

At a club which had just been crowned German champions for the second successive time and was bursting with big-name stars, the signing of the Scot with only a couple of caps to his name was viewed with some surprise by both supporters and players.
But the former St Mirren man scored on his Bundesliga debut and hasn't looked back.

He took advantage of a series of injuries in the Dortmund side to establish himself in a defensive midfield role. Although stars like Portuguese midfielder Paulo Sousa recovered fitness, coach Ottmar Hitzfeld made sure Lambert stayed in the side.

"He's a player you can always rely on and, above all, he's excellent when it comes to winning 50-50 balls," said Thomas Dieckhoff, a sports journalist on the local Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper who follows Borussia.
In a heavy industrial area with few pretensions, players who work hard and give their all for the team are warmly received.
"Although he plays fairly inconspicuously, he's also popular with the fans," Dieckhoff confirmed.
Supporters dressed in the distinctive black and bright yellow Dortmund shirt with Lambert's name and number 14 are now a common sight at the club's Westfalen Stadium.
When Lambert first heard Dortmund were interested in signing him, he jumped at the chance.
"He knew the stadium from playing here in the UEFA Cup with Motherwell and he was very enthusiastic," Dortmund press spokesman Josef Schneck said.
"He fitted in well with the team immediately and he's very highly regarded both within the side and by the fans," he said.
"He's played almost every game for Dortmund this season -- and when he hasn't it's normally because he's been playing for the Scottish national side," Dieckhoff added.

Never more than a squad player for his country before the move to Dortmund, Lambert has now become a first-team regular. At Motherwell, he was always going to struggle in a country where the domestic focus is firmly on the two Glasgow giants.

"If you're not playing for Rangers or Celtic, then you're never seen and you don't get picked," said Lambert, who has retained his strong Scottish accent despite a year away from home. "Maybe that's a wee bit wrong but that's the way it is."

Coach Craig Brown deployed him to particularly good effect against Austria last month when he marked playmaker Andreas Herzog out of the game -- a task he had performed with similar aplomb when Dortmund played Werder Bremen earlier in the season.
Lambert feels he has improved through playing alongside the likes of Sousa and German international Andy Moeller.
"They're brilliant," he said. "You don't realise how good they are until you play with them."

Victory over Juventus would be the crowing glory in a great season for the player, who is by no means overawed at the prospect of taking on a team widely regarded as the best club side in Europe at the moment.
"It doesn't bother me who we're up against," he said. "It's just one team against another."
